Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A Highly Efficient GridBridge Grid Energy Router for Grid Modernization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the development of a cornerstone for reliable electricity and a modernized grid able to evolve alongside emerging customer demands. Reliable electricity is key component of an industrialized market, critical for the information age, and an enabler for non-industrialized regions evolution and eventual world economic contribution. The societal benefit therefore of GridBridge's commercially feasible Grid Energy Router is colossal, as it is the step-function change required to truly orchestrate a grid to match this era. This project will enable numerous hindered technologies and scientific understanding related to energy storage, photovoltaic and other renewable generation, as well as electric vehicles and their correlated fast chargers. Energy savings are also a monumental aspect and are expected to be in the trillions of dollars. Society needs electricity to maintain civilization and an updated grid is imperative for supplying that electricity to an evolved consumer base. GridBridge?s Grid Energy Router will be the crucial component for the modernized grid an enabler for numerous complementary technologies. GridBridge's GER will eventually replace millions of installed legacy grid technologies throughout the world. Furthermore, the continued GridBridge-ERC relationship establishes FREEDM ERC's commercialization ecosystem, which includes 200 diverse students.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 2 project combines various research aspects to commercialize the company?s third breakthrough product for electric utilities, the Grid Energy Router (GER). GridBridge?s Grid Energy Router will be cornerstone for an evolved grid that can integrate renewables and storage, offer dynamic efficiency gains, and intelligently route power. Although there has been early work with power electronics merely focusing in the area of high-voltage conversion, the approaches thus far limit commercialization and manufacturability. GridBridge will combine over three years of company market research and utility voice of the customer, a unique product roadmap, and cutting edge research in the areas of feature implementation and voltage conversion. Keeping in mind the end market, electric utility requirements have been incorporated: highly efficient, cost-competitive, manufacturable within a specific market window, and scalable both to high power and high voltage. This project facilitates a cost-effective and electrically-efficient product design ready for industrialization and ultimately grid integration, while simultaneously incorporating valuable features that justify utility expenditure and meet a market window of need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this SBIR Phase II project was to demonstrate that today?s legacy passive distribution transformers can be replaced by a power electronics-based solution providing multiple features, offering a high efficiency, and a manufactured cost acceptable to electric utilities. To address this need, the team proposed the Grid Energy Router (GER) concept, which controls and routes electrical power between customers in a manner similar to the way the common internet router, found in most households, routes internet information between multiple connected devices such as computers, smart phones and printers.  The GER combines power electronics with autonomous microprocessor-based control and communication capabilities to extends the utilities? ability to control the grid well beyond the substation, to the edge of the power grid.  The output voltage regulation, monitoring and power factor control features of the GER provide a means for the grid operator to significantly improve the power quality and control.  A product power level of 50kVA was targeted, which has not historically been demonstrated within other state of the art work. 

In the Phase II program, GridBridge developed the design for an all-electronic GER that would physically replace the distribution transformer and convert the 7.2kV (MVAC) utility grid voltage to the standard household 240/120V (LVAC) level, and provide GER monitoring, load voltage regulation and power factor control.  The program?s SBIR supplements enabled collaboration with faculty and students from multiple universities.  A modular design approach was adopted with each module containing a MVAC-MVDC rectifier, a MVDC-LVDC converter and a LVDC-LVAC rectifier stage.  These inputs of these bidirectional modules are series connected to accommodate the grid voltage while the outputs are connected in parallel to supply the customer.  This design incorporates an internal DC bus with external connection for DC-based distributed energy resources, such as PV panels and battery energy storage.  A complete module was assembled, the internal control firmware was written, and proper functional operation was demonstrated at LVAC levels.

During this Phase II program, GridBridge recognized a compelling immediate market need for the GER features such as output voltage regulation, power factor correction and remote monitoring.  A more streamlined path to realize quicker customer adoption was to introduce a hybrid approach that combined GridBridge?s GER features at 120/240V with a conventional distribution transformer.  This approach separated the HV-LV conversion development from the power management features development and focused the team on commercialization of a utility-grade device.  Prototype pole mounted GERs were designed, assembled and field tested with multiple utilities of varying size across the US.  These tests exhibited the reliability of the GER across a wide array of electrical and environmental conditions.  Features such as voltage regulation and power factor correction at or near the GER?s 50kVA design limits in the field, are captured in a field test report written by the NRECA.  Included within a wide set of applications related to DER integration and efficiency, the early GER field tests highlighted that the GER design enabled utilities to provide a constant regulated voltage to customers located at various points of the feeder, enabling more feeder capacity and efficiency to be garnered from established conservation voltage reduction (CVR) programs.

Under a following NSF Phase IIB supplement funded development effort with ERMCO (one of the largest US-based manufacturers of distribution transformers, located in Dyersburg, TN), GridBridge?s GER was integrated with ERMCO?s 12kV 50kVA pad mount distribution transformer.  This collaboration enabled GridBridge to refine the GER design for improved reliability, manufacturabilty and incorporate significant thermal, mechanical and electrical design improvements.  The integrated design for this Tiger Pad was completed, fabricated and successfully field tested.  This Phase IIB supplement enabled GridBridge to refine and commercialize the GER.   ERMCO ultimately acquired GridBridge in June 2017, which introduced the ability to conduct large-scale GER manufacturing.  Further adoption of the GER by electric utilities will enable the adoption of DER?s, improved grid efficiency, and increased resiliency that benefits society through reduced utility operating costs and reduced power generation emissions.  The team continues to evolve the GER platform, with future releases focused on direct-connecting distributed energy resources, such as PV and energy storage.
